metadata.title: Effects of nano-graphite content on the characteristics of spark plasma sintered ZiB2–SiC composites

sections.text:
In this study, ZrB2–25 vol% SiC composite containing 0, 2.5, 5, 7.5 and 10 wt% graphite nanoflakes were prepared by spark plasma sintering (SPS) process at 1900 ºC for 7 min under 40 MPa. The fabricated composite samples were compared to examine the influences of nanographite content on the densification, microstructure and mechanical properties of ZrB2–SiCbased ultrahigh temperature ceramics. Fully dense composites were obtained by adding 0-5 wt% nano-graphite, but higher amounts of additive led to a small drop in the sintered density. The growth of ZrB2 grains was moderately hindered by adding nano-graphite but independent of its content. The hardness linearly decreased from 19.5 for the graphite-free ceramic to 12.1 GPa for the sample doped with 10 wt% nano-graphite. Addition of graphite nano-flakes increased the fracture toughness of composites as a value of 8.2 MPa m ½ was achieved by adding 7.5 wt% nano-graphite, twice higher than that measured for the graphite-free sample (4.3 MPa m ½ ). The in-situ formation of ZrC and B4C nano-particles as well as the presence of unreacted graphite nano-flakes led to a remarkable enhancement in fracture toughness through activating several toughening mechanisms such as crack deflection, crack bridging, crack branching and graphite pullout.
Keywords: spark plasma sintering; zirconium diboride; graphite nano-flake; nanocomposite; densification; mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A specific material with unique properties such as oxidation resistance and thermal shock resistance is required for the hypersonic aerospace application in extreme environment. ZrB2based ultrahigh temperature ceramics (UHTCs), is a promising candidate for different high temperature applications owing to low density (6.1 g/cm 3 ) as well as high melting point (above 3000 ºC), elastic modulus, strength and thermal conductivity. However, several studies have demonstrated that adding secondary phases can enhance the sinterability, activate several densification mechanisms to obtain higher relative densities, and boost the mechanical properties such as flexural strength and fracture toughness [1-5]. For example, the addition of SiC to ZrB2based ceramics not only improves the mechanical properties and densification by restricting the growth of ZrB2 grains (due to the removal of surface oxides), but also promotes the oxidation resistance by producing the protective layer of silicate-based glasses containing SiO2, ZrO2 and B2O3. Therefore, many researchers have studied ZrB2–SiC composites and developed different methods for preparation of such materials [6-7].
Due to strong covalent bonding as well as low self-diffusion coefficient of diboride-based ceramics, SiC reinforced ZrB2 composites are commonly fabricated by hot pressing [8-10]. In some cases, reactive hot pressing has been employed to sinter diborides [11-13]. Diboride-based composites were also densified by pressureless sintering owing to the advantages of this method such as the manufacturing of near-net-shape parts [14]. Recently, spark plasma sintering has noticeably employed for densifying ceramic materials [15-16]. Densification improvement of poorly sinterable materials, as a result of using a pulsed or direct current to a green-powder mixture simultaneously with a uniaxial external pressure, is one of the advantages of this process. Another great advantage of this method is to restrict the excessive grain coarsening of powder particles owing to its considerable fast heating rate (~100 ºC /min), compared to other conventional techniques [17-18]. High-energy plasma discharge promotes several densification mechanisms such as activation of particle surface, local melting and vaporization on the powder surface. Therefore, various studies have been carried out on the fabrication of ZrB2-based composites at lower temperatures by spark plasma sintering [19-20].
The addition of sintering aids may also enhance the densification of ZrB2-based materials. These additives can be divided into several categories: liquid phase formers, solid solution formers and reactive agents [21-22]. Refractory metals are used as liquid phase formers. Borides of Ti, Hf, Nb, Ta and Mo are solid solution formers with ZrB2 over a broad range of combinations. Reactive additives such as carbon allotropes, carbides and nitrides can operate as sintering aids through the chemical reactions with oxide impurities on the surface of starting particles [23-24]. For example, the density of ZrB2-based ceramics was found to increase and the grain growth was repressed to a good extent with the addition of carbon up to 5 wt% [25].
Unique properties of graphite such as high Young's modulus, excellent strength, high thermal stability, layered structure that allows for self-lubrication, and high fracture toughness make it a suitable candidate material for high temperature applications. It is clearly known that the addition of graphite to a composite sample, which has weak interface with the matrix phase, leads to the fracture toughness improvement in brittle materials through deflecting the propagating cracks [26-29]. However, until now, a few studies have been done on the graphite-reinforced ZrB2–SiC ceramic composites. The fracture toughness of hot pressed ZrB2 (without SiC reinforcement) was increased by the addition of graphite flakes; however, the hardness and flexural strength were slightly decreased [30]. Improved densification, fracture toughness and flexural strength as well as fine-grained microstructures were obtained by adding 10-15 vol% graphite flake to ZrB2– 20 vol% SiC composites fabricated by hot pressing [31-34]. A fully dense 10 vol% nanographite reinforced ZrB2–20 vol% SiC composite was achieved by hot pressing process. The interfacial reactions eliminated the oxide impurities which led to the formation of finer microstructure and increased hardness and indentation fracture toughness, in comparison with the monolithic ZrB2 ceramic and ZrB2–SiC composite [35].
In the present work, ZrB2–25 vol% SiC ceramics, including the different amounts of graphite nano-flakes (0, 2.5, 5, 7.5 and 10 wt%), are fabricated by spark plasma sintering. The effects of graphite content on the microstructure and mechanical properties (hardness and fracture toughness) of ZrB2–SiC composites are investigated in detail. Although the fabrication of fullydense ZrB2–SiC UHTCs can be possible using the SPS process, even without the graphite sinteradditive, the main purpose of nano-graphite addition in this research is due to its toughening effects on such ceramic composites.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and process
sections.text:
In this study, ZrB2, SiC and graphite nano-flake powders were used as the starting materials. The characteristics of these powders are presented in Table 1. At first, the powders were weighted based on the designated volumes and weight percentages listed in Table 2. Then, the powders were separately dispersed in ethanol by 1 h ultrasonication (Daihan WUC-D10H, Korea). After that, the powders were ultrasonically dispersed together in ethanol for extra 30 min. Subsequently, the slurries were heated at 150 °C for 2 h using a magnetic stirring hot plate (Heidolph MR 3001 K, Germany) followed by 12 h drying in an oven (Memmert Universal Oven Um, Germany) at a temperature of 110 °C. Then fully dried composite powder mixtures were milled in an agate mortar and passed through a sieve (mesh 100).
The obtained powder mixtures were loaded in to a graphite die and lined with flexible graphite foils to fabricate disk-shaped samples with a diameter of 30 mm and a thickness of ~6 mm. The spark plasma process was carried out in a vacuum hot pressing furnace (SPS-20T-10, China) at a temperature of 1900 °C for a soaking time of 7 min under an externally applied pressure of 40 MPa.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text:
The bulk density of the as-sintered samples was determined by the Archimedes technique and the theoretical density was obtained according to the rule of mixture. Based on the supplier's datasheet, the theoretical densities of ZrB2, SiC and graphite were supposed 6.1, 3.2 and 2.25 g/cm 3 , respectively. The relative density was calculated as the ratio between the bulk and the theoretical density values. The microstructure of as-received materials as well as the polished and fracture surfaces of as-sintered parts was investigated using a FE-SEM (Mira3, Tescan, Czech Republic) along with an EDS processor (DXP-X10P) for chemical analysis. The average ZrB2 grain size in the as-sintered composites was estimated by measuring more than 150 grains
using the ImageJ (1.44p, Wayne Rasband, USA) image analyzer. The XRD analysis (Philips PW1730) was performed to characterize the crystalline phases in the starting powders and the sintered parts. Thermodynamical data were extracted by the HSC Chemistry (Outokumpu Research Oy, Finland) software. The hardness was measured by Vickers indentation (HV5) on the polished surfaces of ceramics using a Koopa Pazhoohesh (KM2/01-92123, Iran) hardness test equipment with a 49-N load for 15 s (average values of 5 indentations). The indentation fracture toughness was evaluated using the Anstis equation (Eq. 1 [36]) through the direct measurement of lengths of diagonal cracks induced at the corners of Vickers' indenter:
( )
⁄
⁄ (1)
where E is the Young's modulus, Hv is the Vickers hardness, L is the load of indentation and C is half of the radial crack length. The Young's modulus was estimated by a formula (Eq. 2) proposed by Nielsen [37] and the crack lengths were measured using an optical microscope (Nikon Eclipse MA100, Japan).
(2)
In this equation, E0 is the Young's modulus of a hypothetical fully dense composite estimated by the rule of mixtures, P is the porosity in vol% and ρ is the Nielsen's shape factor supposed 0.4 in such materials. Elastic moduli of ZrB2, SiC and graphite were considered 500, 410 and 15 GPa, respectively [34, 35].

sections.heading: 3.1. Densification and microstructure evolution
sections.text:
The FE-SEM images and XRD patterns of raw materials are presented in Fig. 1. Fig. 1a shows that the size of ZrB2 powders is <2 μm (as it was claimed in the supplier’s datasheet) and only hexagonal ZrB2 peaks were detected by XRD analysis. The presence of several 1-μm sized SiC particles is seen in Fig. 1b; however, most of them are <500 nm. The X-ray diffraction pattern presented in Fig. 1b verifies the hexagonal SiC as the singular crystalline phase. The SEM nanograph of Fig. 1c displays the graphite flakes with nano-sized thickness (<100 nm). This
nanomaterial contains hexagonal graphite as the major recognized phase, but trace of rhombohedral graphite is also detected by XRD test.
Fig. 2 shows the relative densities of spark plasma sintered ZrB2–SiC-based composites as a function of nano-graphite content. A relative density of 99.9% was achieved for ZSG0 sample after sintering at 1900 ºC for 7 min under 40 MPa. Hence, it seems that fabricating a relatively fully dense ZrB2–SiC ceramic is possible, without adding the graphite nano-flakes in the powder mixture. However, slight increase in the density occurred after adding nano-sized graphite up to 5 wt%, as relative density values of 100% and 100.7% were obtained for ZSG2.5 and ZSG5 composites, respectively. The uncommon relative density of >100% is related to the in-situ formed ZrC phase with a true density of 6.7 g/cm 3 , higher than those of ZrB2, SiC and graphite as powder mixture, which has not inserted in the relative density estimation by the rule of mixtures. In the micron-sized SiC reinforced ZrB2-based ceramics, fabricated by hot pressing at 1850 ºC for 60 min under 20 MPa, the relative density was improved from 93.2% to 99.6% by adding 5 wt% graphite nano-flakes [35]. Fabrication of fully dense ZrB2–SiC ceramic composites were also reported by the addition of micron-sized graphite flakes and hot pressing at 1900 ºC for 60 min under 30 MPa [38]. The negative role of extra graphite addition (>5 wt%) on the densification of ZSG samples is clearly seen in Fig. 2, since the relative densities of ZSG7.5 and ZSG10 composites have decreased to 99.7% and 98.3%, respectively.
Fig. 3 shows the backscattered FE-SEM of the polished surfaces of spark plasma sintered ceramic composites. It can be clearly seen in Fig. 3a that the ZrB2 and SiC particles have completely sintered together in the ZSG0 ceramic and the SiC grains are distributed homogenously in the ZrB2 matrix. As this sample has reached the theoretical density (99.9%), no porosity is detected in its polished surface. The mean ZrB2 grain size in the ZSG0 sample is 4.1 µm; hence, in comparison with the 2-µm grain size of the starting ZrB2 particle, no extreme grain growth was observed during the spark plasma sintering. Such an observation not only is related to the positive role of SiC addition on the hindrance of abnormal grain growth in ZrB2-based ceramics, but also can be attributed to the small holding time of 7 min at the final sintering temperature of SPS process.
The microstructure of ZSG2.5 sample with a relative density of 100% (Fig. 2) and a mean ZrB2 grain size of 3.5 µm is shown in Fig. 3b. Concurrent addition of SiC and graphite to the ZrB2
matrix in the ZSG2.5 composite has not meaningfully affected the densification process, compared to the graphite-free ZSG0 sample, because both of them have reached their theoretical densities. However, the addition of graphite together with SiC had a better impact on minimizing the grain growth. The SiC grains and graphite flakes are uniformly distributed in the ZrB2 matrix (Fig. 3b). The FE-SEM fractograph of ZSG2.5 sample (Fig. 4) also shows such a uniform distribution of graphite flakes, most of them are nano-sized (<100 nm), in the as-sintered microstructure.
Fig. 3c displays the microstructure of a fully dense (100.7%) ZSG5 composite with an average grain size of 3.3 µm for ZrB2 matrix. Compared to the ZSG2.5 sample, the double graphite content in this composite, not only resulted in the relative density value of slightly more than 100%, but also acted as a relatively better grain growth inhibitor. Such an observation may be related to the in-situ formation of new phases during the SPS process which have higher theoretical densities than the maternal phases, but have not considered in the relative density calculations based on the rule of mixtures. More explanations about such in-situ formed phases will be discussed in the next paragraphs. It should be noted that some graphite flakes have been picked from the polished surfaces (Fig. 3c-e) during the polishing process, may be due to the soft nature of graphite phases.
Few pores are seen as fine black-colored areas in the microstructure of ZSG7.5 sample (Fig. 3d) which can be related to its relative density value of 99.7%. It seems that the higher amounts of graphite as an additive in the ZrB2–SiC composites lead to the agglomeration of graphite flakes which cannot fully joined together or to other components; hence, some pores are remained in the as-sintered parts. Fig. 5a shows the presence of some nano-sized graphite flakes at the interface of ZrB2/SiC grains in the FE-SEM fractograph of ZSG7.5 sample. High amount of carbon element in the EDS spectrum of such interfacial phases (Fig. 5b) verifies them as remained graphite nano-flakes in the final microstructure. The mean ZrB2 grain size in this sample is estimated as 3.4 µm which does not show a sharp variation, compared to the other graphite-doped composites.
The microstructure of ZSG10 sample (Fig. 3e), with a relative density of 98.3% based on Fig. 2, contains higher porosity values, contrasted to the other investigated ceramic composites. More agglomerated graphite nano-flakes are clearly seen in Fig. 3e; nevertheless, the mean ZrB2 grain
size in ZSG10 composite is measured as 3.2 µm as the most fine-grained microstructure in this research work. Fig. 6a exhibits the in-situ formation of nano-sized ZrC particles at the interfaces of ZrB2/graphite phases in the SEM image of fracture surface of ZSG10 sample. The sharp peaks of zirconium and carbon elements in the EDS spectrum of such interfacial nano-particles (Fig. 6b) characterize them as ZrC phase. Although the ZrC has a relative density of 6.7 g/cm 3 , higher than those of other existed phases, which is expected to increase the density of resultant composite, the presence of agglomerated graphite flakes has not allowed the material to reach 100% relative density.

sections.heading: 3.2. Thermodynamic and kinetic aspects
sections.text:
Fig. 7 displays the Gibbs free energy of the possible chemical reactions between the components in the nano-graphite doped ZrB2–SiC as a function of temperature up to 1900 ºC. Although SiC is generally known as a non-reactive additive in ZrB2-based composites, the densification improvement in ZrB2–SiC ceramic can be related to the chemical reaction of SiC with the oxide impurities on the surface of ZrB2 particles, based on the following reaction:
5SiC + 2ZrO2 + 2B2O3 = 2ZrB2 + 5SiO (g) + 5CO (g) (3)
As it can be seen in Fig 8, this reaction thermodynamically occurs at >1758 °C, which leads to the formation of ZrB2 together with volatilizable SiO and CO gasses. Graphite nano-flakes not only can reduce the surface oxides (ZrO2 and B2O3) of ZrB2, but also the oxide impurity of SiC (SiO2) in accord with Eq. 4:
8C + ZrO2 + B2O3 + SiO2 = ZrB2 + SiC + 7CO (g) (4)
This chemical reaction occurs at >1512 ºC; remarkably at temperatures lower than that needed for the development of Eq. 3. Therefore, the graphite nano-flakes thermodynamically act as the dominant reductive additive. In another viewpoint, since SiC particles have 3-dimantional shapes and are larger than the graphite nano-flakes with a 2-dimentional morphology, the surface available for reductive reactions by carbonaceous additives is more than that of SiC particles. Thus, the rate of reducing oxides with nano-sized graphite is higher than that of SiC.
The formation of ZrC and B4C phases is also thermodynamically favorable at the temperatures below than the final sintering temperature of 1900 ºC, based on the following equations:
ZrO2 + 3C = ZrC + 2CO (g) (5)
2B2O3 + 7C = B4C + 6CO (g) (6)
On the other words, the graphite may supplementally react with ZrO2 at 1669 ºC to form ZrC and with B2O3 at 1567 ºC to form B4C. The XRD analysis (Fig. 8) were also proved the formation of zirconium and boron carbides in the ZSG10 sample. The in-situ formed ZrC nano-particles at the interface of graphite nano-flakes with the surface oxide (ZrO2) of ZrB2 was already shown in Fig. 6. Therefore, kinetically and thermodynamically, nano-sized carbonaceous sinter additives have the major reduction role in ZrB2–SiC ceramics.

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical properties
sections.text:
The hardness values of spark plasma sintered ZrB2–SiC-based composites as a function of nanographite content are presented in Fig. 9. The hardness of ZSG0 sample with a relative density of 99.9 is 19.5 GPa as the hardest composite material in this research work. A hardness value of 13.1 GPa was reported for a hot pressed ZrB2–SiC ceramic with similar composition but a relative density of 93.2% [35]. Such a comparison shows the importance of reaching full density on the maximum attainable hardness value for a material. As it can be clearly seen in Fig. 9, the hardness of ZSG composites linearly decreases with increasing the amount of nano-graphite additive. The minimum hardness value of 12.1 GPa belongs to ZSG10 composite, which is ~40% lower than that of ZSG0 ceramic as the graphite-free sample. As all the ZSG samples have approached their theoretical density (relative density of all composites are greater than 98%), the drop in the hardness values with increasing the nano-graphite content can be related to the intrinsic softness of graphite phases present in the final microstructure.
The Young's moduli of ZSG0, ZSG2.5, ZSG5, ZSG7.5 and ZSG10 samples were estimated 478, 451, 428, 407 and 385 GPa, respectively, using the rule of mixtures and the Nielsen formula. Fig. 10 shows the variation of fracture toughness of ZrB2–SiC-based composites as a function of nano-graphite content. The fracture toughness of graphite-free (ZSG0) sample is 4.3 MPa m ½
and increases with the addition of more graphite nano-flakes. As a comparison, the fracture toughness of ZSG7.5 composite (8.2 MPa m ½ ) is approximately two times greater than that of the ZSG0 ceramic. It should be noted that the fracture toughness assessment of ZSG10 sample was unreliable to be made by the Vickers method, because the lengths of indentation induced cracks at the corners of indenter could not be the observed and measured due to the interactions of cracks with the agglomerated graphite nano-flakes. Such a remarkable enhancement in the fracture toughness of ZSG7.5 sample can be attributed to the synergistic toughening of ZrB2based ceramic by submicron SiC particles and graphite nano-flakes. Achieving a relatively finer microstructure, the in-situ formation of ZrC and B4C nano-particles as well as the partially presence of initial additives in final microstructure can be nominated as fracture toughness boosters.
FE-SEM micrographs of the indentation-induced crack paths, originated from the Vickers indentation corners, in the polished surfaces of ZSG0 and ZSG7.5 samples are presented in Fig. 11. The crack path in the ZSG7.5 composite (Fig. 11a) is more branched and twisty than that of the ZSG0 sample (Fig. 11b). Generally, the interaction of an indentation-induced crack with the secondary phases in a composite material causes the crack deflection, a significant toughening mechanism. Hence, the number and angles of deflections in the ZSG7.5 composite are greater than that of the ZSG0 sample, because of the variety of initially added and consequently in-situ formed secondary phases in the graphite-reinforced sample. A more twisting path for the crack is a qualitative evidence that more energy can be absorbed during the crack propagation process. Beside the crack deflection, other toughening mechanisms such as crack bridging and break of large SiC grains are seen in the ZSG0 ceramic. Crack branching is observed in the ZSG7.5 composite, may be due to the interaction of propagating crack with the soft phase of graphite. The fracture toughness improvement of ZSG7.5 sample can also be attributed to the high aspect ratio of graphite nano-flakes and their weaker interfacial bonding with the other phases, which boosts the opportunities of crack deflection and branching. Moreover, the FE-SEM fractograph of ZSG7.5 composite (Fig. 5a) reveals the possibility of nano-graphite pullout as another toughening mechanism in this sample. It should be noted that the interactions between the indentation cracks and microstructure are under control of the residual stresses caused by the mismatch in the thermomechanical properties of different existed phases in the composite
material. The strain contours observed around the graphite nano-flakes in Fig. 5a may be originated by such residual stresses.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: Five ZrB2–SiC-based ceramic composites, reinforced with 0-10 wt% graphite nano-flakes, were fabricated by spark plasma sintering at 1900 ºC for 7 min under 40 MPa. All composite samples reached >98% theoretical densities, but adding up to 5 wt% graphite resulted in fully dense parts. The addition of graphite led to the removal of oxide impurities and consequently the formation of ultrafine ZrC and B4C phases. Compared to the graphite-free ZrB2–SiC ceramic with a mean ZrB2 grain size of 4.1 µm, the grain growth of ZrB2 was slightly decreased to 3.2-3.5 µm by adding nano-graphite independent of its content (2.5-10 wt%). By increasing the graphite content in the ZrB2–SiC-based ceramics, the hardness linearly deceased from 19.5 GPa for the graphitefree sample to 12.1 GPa for the 10 wt% graphite doped ZrB2–SiC ceramic. The fracture toughness significantly improved to 8.2 MPa m ½ by the addition of 7.5 wt% nano-graphite, compared to the graphite-free sample with a fracture toughness of 4.3 MPa m ½ . Some toughening mechanisms such as crack deflection, bridging, branching and graphite pullout were observed due to the presence of graphite nano-flakes and the formation of interfacial ZrC and B4C nano-particles in ZrB2–SiC nanocomposites.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, ZrB2–25 vol% SiC composite containing 0, 2.5, 5, 7.5 and 10 wt% graphite nanoflakes were prepared by spark plasma sintering (SPS) process at 1900 oC for 7 min under 40 MPa. The fabricated composite samples were compared to examine the influences of nanographite content on the densification, microstructure and mechanical properties of ZrB2–SiCbased ultrahigh temperature ceramics. Fully dense composites were obtained by adding 0-5 wt% nano-graphite, but higher amounts of additive led to a small drop in the sintered density. The growth of ZrB2 grains was moderately hindered by adding nano-graphite but independent of its content. The hardness linearly decreased from 19.5 for the graphite-free ceramic to 12.1 GPa for the sample doped with 10 wt% nano-graphite. Addition of graphite nano-flakes increased the fracture toughness of composites as a value of 8.2 MPa m 1⁄2 was achieved by adding 7.5 wt% nano-graphite, twice higher than that measured for the graphite-free sample (4.3 MPa m 1⁄2 ). The in-situ formation of ZrC and B4C nano-particles as well as the presence of unreacted graphite nano-flakes led to a remarkable enhancement in fracture toughness through activating several toughening mechanisms such as crack deflection, crack bridging, crack branching and graphite pullout.
